messages.text:
I was arguing with my university teachers that they don't need to invent their own "pseudo-code" for algorithms to make it look "clean" enough because they can just use Julia. The counter-argument was that when you invent your own "pseudo-code", it gives you certain freedom when defining algorithms, thus it's necessary to use that kind of syntax instead of some real programming language.

I almost got them to approve my example Julia function as a valid "pseudo-code" (they didn't know that it's actually Julia code), but for some reason, the way how loops are defined, `for i = 1:n`  was not good enough. A teacher didn't understand does the loop end to `n` or `n-1`. However, if written like in their "pseudo-code" approach,  `for i = 1 to n` , is was somehow more "clear". Everything else was almost acceptable. `push!` was "questionable operation", but `append!` was ok. `f(x) = 2*x` was "not understood", but `f = x -> 2x` was ok.

elements.text:

messages.text:
I’ve read that Julia has been used for HPC but that the necessary optimizations made the code like FORTRAN; e.g., loop unrolling.  Can anyone tell me about this?

I wonder if the traditional focus on writing good FORTRAN and C compilers on HPC hardware is limiting the field.  An equivalent code base could be constructed from Julia and Rust, both based on the LLVM.  Focusing compiler optimizations and hardware design on one virtual machine could allow what once were improvements to only either language to become benefits to both.

elements.text: I’ve read that Julia has been used for HPC but that the necessary optimizations made the code like FORTRAN; e.g., loop unrolling.  Can anyone tell me about this?

I wonder if the traditional focus on writing good FORTRAN and C compilers on HPC hardware is limiting the field.  An equivalent code base could be constructed from Julia and Rust, both based on the LLVM.  Focusing compiler optimizations and hardware design on one virtual machine could allow what once were improvements to only either language to become benefits to both.

messages.text: The reason Fortran is used is not because it’s better than alternatives, it’s used because there are MOUNTAINS of legacy Fortran code that HPC people want to rely on.

elements.text: The reason Fortran is used is not because it’s better than alternatives, it’s used because there are MOUNTAINS of legacy Fortran code that HPC people want to rely on.

messages.text: People are using Julia and other languages in HPC, but there will be no sharp transition. It’ll happen very gradually

elements.text: People are using Julia and other languages in HPC, but there will be no sharp transition. It’ll happen very gradually

messages.text: <@U6795JH6H>, <@U67D54KS8>; <@UDB26738Q> and I just had a long conversation in which we concluded that we agree that the stdlibs should not have special accommodations in the load path, and should be required to be present in the environment like anything else, but that the default environment should include them when first created. messages.text:
The following code segment causes julia to eat up more and more memory over time (v1.5.3)
```makesimpletype(x::Dict{T,T}) where {T<:Integer} = 
    Array{T}(vcat([[child parent] for (child, parent) ∈ x]...))


d = Dict( n => n for n=1:1000000)

for n = 1000000 .+(1:100)
    d[n] = n
    mat = makesimpletype(d)
    GC.gc()
    println("$(round(Sys.maxrss()/2^20,digits=2)) MiB, ", size(mat))
end```
Can anyone reproduce / explain? (I'm aware that the above function is far from optimal)

elements.text: The following code segment causes julia to eat up more and more memory over time (v1.5.3)

makesimpletype(x::Dict{T,T}) where {T<:Integer} = 
    Array{T}(vcat([[child parent] for (child, parent) ∈ x]...))


d = Dict( n => n for n=1:1000000)

for n = 1000000 .+(1:100)
    d[n] = n
    mat = makesimpletype(d)
    GC.gc()
    println("$(round(Sys.maxrss()/2^20,digits=2)) MiB, ", size(mat))
end
Can anyone reproduce / explain? (I'm aware that the above function is far from optimal)

messages.text:
I noticed something interesting comparing these two docker images:
```jupyter/datascience-notebook                                      latest               a665c8ddeb27   3 days ago     3.91GB
julia                                                             1.6.0-beta1-buster   8bebd5c999f5   2 weeks ago    484MB```
3.91GB vs. 484MB is quite a lot. If you add miniconda and jupyterlab to that julia image, it’s still just 1.14GB.
```julia-miniconda-jupyterlab                                        latest               5ab826013af0   About a minute ago   1.14GB```
This costs money if you store them in Google/Amazon registry.

messages.text: What is the convention for converting a object `A` to `B` without copying internal fields of `A` even if `A` is mutable ? It cannot be `convert` because [the docs is clear we should copy). It cannot be `unsafe_convert` as this converts to C. Can it be a constructor ? Is there another variant of convert for that ?

messages.text: well, `B = A` is one way to do it. edit: you mean you have your own type with the same fields as SparseMatrixCSC? `SparseMatrixCSC{Float64,Int}(x.m, x.n, x.colptr, x.rowval, x.nzval)` should work

messages.text: Hi. I didn’t find a specific channel for questions about JuMP. Please, advise me if there is a better place for this. Anyway. It is my first time using JuMP and SumOfSquares. I would like to use it to get bounds over time-averages of quantities of solutions of differential equations. I started following the examples in <https://jump.dev/SumOfSquares.jl/stable/>, for bounds of functions and for searching for Lyapunov functions. The only solver I saw being used there is `CSDP`. But I would like to use `SDPA-GMP` since it was the one that I saw working in the MATLAB ecosystem. My Julia code with `CSDP` does not converge properly. But I get an error when replacing `CSDP`with `SDPAFamily`. Is there something else I should do? The error I get is the same error that appears when I replace `CSDP.Optimizer` by `SDPAFamily.Optimizer` in the Lyapunov example <https://jump.dev/SumOfSquares.jl/stable/generated/Lyapunov%20Function%20Search/>

> in Julia we haven’t quite found the right interface yet. Either you have to work at the low level IR, or at high level method dispatch. messages.text: I'm sure this has been discussed a million times, but is there a reason Julia can't (or shouldn't) cache generated machine code and method resolution paths?

elements.text: I'm sure this has been discussed a million times, but is there a reason Julia can't (or shouldn't) cache generated machine code and method resolution paths?

messages.text: Because they depend exactly on what packages you already have loaded and what has been defined so far. If you cache them every time, there's a combinatorial explosion in the things you cache and you'll just run out of disk space

elements.text: Because they depend exactly on what packages you already have loaded and what has been defined so far. If you cache them every time, there's a combinatorial explosion in the things you cache and you'll just run out of disk space

messages.text: That makes sense.

elements.text: That makes sense.

messages.text: It strikes me that one of the main times this would be problematic is if you're doing something "weird" like type piracy, but I guess that's part of Julia semantics and package maintainers depend on that kind of thing when creating packages.

messages.text: I think more measurement of code invalidations needs to happen, and how to cut down on that (which <@UC8821DPY> has been doing), but in the future, I think we might get the the point where it would make sense to automatically cache generated machine code in shared libraries.  There’s no reason the cache would make things run out of space, if it cleared out old versions that weren’t being used anymore.

elements.text: I think more measurement of code invalidations needs to happen, and how to cut down on that (which

has been doing), but in the future, I think we might get the the point where it would make sense to automatically cache generated machine code in shared libraries.  There’s no reason the cache would make things run out of space, if it cleared out old versions that weren’t being used anymore.

root.text:
<https://github.com/google-research/dex-lang/discussions/489#discussioncomment-315053>

> in Julia we haven’t quite found the right interface yet. Either you have to work at the low level IR, or at high level method dispatch. In PL theory, semantics are often expressed compositionally in terms of rules in the grammar. I wonder if something like that could work — a bit like Cassette but able to handle control flow and constructs other than function application.
Interesting discussion about compiler transforms in Dex and Julia by <@U66G4838Q> and <@U6A936746>

messages.text:
Is there a way to define a parametric struct type, where some of the member types are "computed" from the parameters of the type? Here's a stupid example to illustrate what I mean (note: this is an artificial example, not what I actually want):
```struct VectorWithRepresentative{S <: AbstractVector}
  vec::S
  rep::eltype(S)
end```
As far as I could tell, the only way to do something like this seems to be with a macro? Am I wrong? If I am right: is there perhaps something like this somewhere already?

elements.text: Is there a way to define a parametric struct type, where some of the member types are "computed" from the parameters of the type? Here's a stupid example to illustrate what I mean (note: this is an artificial example, not what I actually want):

struct VectorWithRepresentative{S <: AbstractVector}
  vec::S
  rep::eltype(S)
end
As far as I could tell, the only way to do something like this seems to be with a macro? Am I wrong? If I am right: is there perhaps something like this somewhere already?

messages.text:
Is there a resource I could use to learn why and when extra memory may be allocated when a Julia function is called, when it doesn't appear to be strictly needed for execution?

Example being <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/issues/37639>

I understand the immediate issue is caused by disabling optimization of the throw block, but I want to understand why the compiler thinks that means it needs to pre-emptively allocate more memory when that block isn't likely to be executed. I'm assuming there are good reasons for the behavior, I just don't know what they are.

How do I get started?

messages.text:
Yesterday I gave an internal talk inside my company about Julia. The talked was aimed at C++, MATLAB and python developers and one of the questions was: "What is the added advantage compared to python? As python can also do exactly similar things?". I answer to the best of my ability, but now I wonder what people responses would be.
Note: My answer emphasized that python cannot do the same as Julia

messages.text:
In C# (idk about other languages), a foreach loop using an iterator throws an exception if the underlying collection was modified while iterating. This prevents a common class of bugs.

Would this be possible to implement? Is there a reason someone might desire iterating over a collection that has mutated mid-iteration?

messages.text:
Hi ... I am/was curious if someone has set up a local or "on-prem" julia package repository? And can point to useful material or best practices for embarking on such an endeavor?
Would syncing the whole julia github package universe be the only possibility and how does one keep track of updates and "potentialy" breaking inter-package dependencies? Am I just not aware of a similar thing or is there also something in place that does some QA (quality assurance) on these things like CRAN for R packages? Plus Julia version compatibility of packages etc.

elements.text:

Would syncing the whole julia github package universe be the only possibility and how does one keep track of updates and "potentialy" breaking inter-package dependencies? Am I just not aware of a similar thing or is there also something in place that does some QA (quality assurance) on these things like CRAN for R packages? messages.text: Why don't people use VegaLite.jl instead of Plots.jl? Seems soooo much faster! (Maybe I'm missing something)

elements.text: Why don't people use VegaLite.jl instead of Plots.jl? Seems soooo much faster! (Maybe I'm missing something)

messages.text: it's missing a ton of standard features. 3D for one.

elements.text: it's missing a ton of standard features. 3D for one.

messages.text: VegaLite really comes out of the grammar of graphics corner/stats world, and 3D is kind of not a thing there :slightly_smiling_face: But agreed, that is certainly the biggest thing that is missing.

elements.text: VegaLite really comes out of the grammar of graphics corner/stats world, and 3D is kind of not a thing there
But agreed, that is certainly the biggest thing that is missing.

messages.text: Type support.

elements.text: Type support.

messages.text: Definitely if you do data science stuff only it can be a good option, along with Gadfly.

elements.text: Definitely if you do data science stuff only it can be a good option, along with Gadfly.

messages.text: Yep, also true! VegaLite is a grammar of graphics type thing, so you need to buy into that approach, and that is just a very distinct philosophy for plotting than say the recipe philosophy of Plots. But if you DO want the GoG thing, it works pretty well. Plus it has a large dev team behind it that is constantly working on it, so it is gaining new stuff all the time.

elements.text: Yep, also true! VegaLite is a grammar of graphics type thing, so you need to buy into that approach, and that is just a very distinct philosophy for plotting than say the recipe philosophy of Plots. But if you DO want the GoG thing, it works pretty well. Plus it has a large dev team behind it that is constantly working on it, so it is gaining new stuff all the time.

messages.text: AlgebraOfGraphics.jl is a fairly interesting take on GoG to follow

elements.text: AlgebraOfGraphics.jl is a fairly interesting take on GoG to follow

messages.text: Though the thing I would add is, don't be afraid of PackageCompiler. It's fairly good, easy to use, and stable these days. Package compiling a few common libraries should be more standard.
